metadata.title: Various carbohydrate precursors dehydration to 5-HMF in an acidic biphasic system under microwave heating using betaine as a co-catalyst

Fig. 1 Effect of the temperature on the HMF production starting from d-fructose and d-glucose. Reaction conditions: hexose (180mg), betaine (0.07g), HCOOH (0.25mg), water (4.0mL), MW, 1h. Fig. 2 Various loadings of hexoses versus HMF yield. Reaction conditions: betaine (0.07g), HCOOH (0.25g), water (4mL), MW, 160°C (for d-fructose) and 190°C (for d-glucose), 1h. Fig. 3 Effect of the water to MIBK phase ratio (v/v) on the HMF production. Reaction conditions: hexose (180mg), betaine (0.07g), HCOOH (0.25g), water–MIBK (4mL), MW, 160°C (for d-fructose) and 190°C (for d-glucose), 1h. Fig. 4 Reaction profile for dehydration of d-fructose (Fig. 4a) and d-glucose (Fig. 4b) in presence of betaine–HCOOH at varying temperatures: Reaction conditions: hexose (180mg), betaine (0.07g), HCOOH (0.25g), water–MIBK (4mL), MW, 160°C (for d-fructose) and 190°C (for d-glucose). Fig. 5 Reusability of the aqueous phase containing betaine and HCOOH for fructose dehydration to HMF. Reaction conditions: d-fructose (180mg), betaine (0.07g), HCOOH (0.25g), water–MIBK (3:1, v/v), MW, 160°C, 40min. Fig. 6 Temperature reaction and HMF yield from starch and cellulose. Reaction conditions: polysaccharide (180mg), betaine (0.07g), HCOOH (0.50g), water–MIBK (2:2, v/v), MW, 1hour. Fig. 7 Time residence versus HMF yield. Reaction conditions: (a) microcrystalline cellulose (180mg), betaine (0.07g), HCOOH (0.5g), MW, 200°C; (b) soluble starch (180mg), betaine (0.07g), HCOOH (0.5g), MW, 190°C. Scheme 1 Respective d-glucose–d-fructose isomerization and then d-fructose dehydration into HMF and their relative associated kinetic rates in a biphasic system under microwave irradiation. Scheme 2 Each steps of microcrystalline cellulose transformation into HMF by using betaine–HCOOH catalytic system in water–MIBK biphasic system under microwave irradiation. Various carbohydrate precursors dehydration to 5-HMF in an acidic biphasic system under microwave heating using betaine as a co-catalyst Frederic Delbecq a YanTao Wang b Christophe Len b ⁎ a Ecole Supérieure de Chimie Organique et Minérale (ESCOM), 1 allée du Réseau Jean-Marie Buckmaster, F-60200 Compiègne, France Ecole Supérieure de Chimie Organique et Minérale (ESCOM) 1 allée du Réseau Jean-Marie Buckmaster Compiègne F-60200 France b Sorbonne Universités, Université de Technologie de Compiègne (UTC), Centre de Recherches Royallieu, CS 60319, F-60203 Compiègne Cedex, France Sorbonne Universités, Université de Technologie de Compiègne (UTC), Centre de Recherches Royallieu, CS 60319 Compiègne Cedex F-60203 France ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A mixture of betaine–formic acid was employed to convert d-glucose and d-fructose into 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) with high selectivity and also for the direct conversion of water-soluble starch and microcrystalline insoluble cellulose. The reactions were performed in average of temperature found between 160 and 200°C regarding the nature of the substrate. The reactions were carried out under microwave heating and performed in a water–MIBK biphasic system at different ratios. In each case, the specific optimized condition gave values of HMF yields of 82%, 55%, 54% and 47% respectively from d-fructose, d-glucose, water-soluble starch and cellulose microcrystalline powder. Keywords 5-HMF Biphasic system Hexoses Polysaccharide Microwave aided dehydration 1 Introduction In a context of severe fuel-based depletion, the dehydration of carbohydrate became one of the most important strategies to produce high valuable starting material such as furan derived compounds. One of them, 5-HMF is a platform molecule usually obtained from dehydration of hexoses, known as the most abundant monomer sub-units and the main components of starch and other related cellulosic biomass. In comparison to furfural, 5-HMF is also recognized as top-value bio-based chemicals useful for its conversion into biofuel and other type of valuable organic compounds. Overall, HMF is known as the precursor of 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) through the oxidation of primary alcohol and carbonyl group hold by the furan core of HMF. FDCA is currently employed as a potent substitute of terephtalic acid in the preparation of various polyesters. Moreover, HMF could be used as a key-compound in the chemical industry for the preparation of fuel additives such as alkyl levulinates. Generally, HMF is largely produced in water under conventional heating by dehydrating d-fructose or d-glucose in presence of a homogeneous catalyst such as inorganic mineral acid (HCl, H2SO4, etc.) [1,2] or a Lewis acid [3]. The heterogeneous catalysts such as acidic resins, sulfated solids [4–6] and zeolite [7] are also potent for this reaction. However, during the process, formic acid (FA) and levulinic acid (LA) are generally generated by the rehydration of HMF lowering its yield. To prevent from this undesired phenomenon, it is possible to replace water or add a polar miscible solvent such as high boiling point dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO), acetonitrile or tetrahydrofuran (THF) [5], however the recovery of the desired HMF appeared to be here more complicated or high energy consuming. Like DMSO, ionic liquids are a very convenient medium for dehydrating the hexoses in anhydrous condition, unfortunately their high water solubility make difficult the separation of the HMF. Beside, when carried out in sole water, at the higher temperatures, HMF can decompose into black carbonaceous insoluble side-product called humin. To avoid these undesired resinification and cross-polymerization, non-miscible solvents such as the gamma valerolactone (GVL) or aromatic solvents could be employed as the extractive liquid to isolate the compound improving the HMF selectivity [7–16]. In order to accelerate the reaction in parallel to possible selectivity improvement, microwave heating is the most powerful tool for dehydrating hexoses [17–19], especially in a biphasic system involving methylisobutylketone (MIBK) as the protective solvent. During the last decades, efforts were made to find the best conditions upon microwave irradiation and maximize the yield of formed HMF from water-soluble starch and microcrystalline cellulose direct transformation. The entire strategy reported in this study was based on the recent work of De Oliveira Vigier et al. [20]. This research team was able to produce HMF in 84% yield from d-fructose using betaine hydrochloride as the catalyst under conventional heating involving an atypic biphasic system involving a deep eutectic solvent and MIBK as the extractive solvent. In the first part of the present work, we tried to demonstrate the potential of betaine in contact with formic acid to produce in situ some kind of acidic ionic liquid as a catalyst for converting simple carbohydrates and d-glucose rich materials into HMF avoiding the formation of undesired levulinic acid by-product. In the second part, after transferred the procedure to the quite stable microcrystalline cellulose, some attempt of a simplified kinetic model for its related transformation into HMF was given with some explanations. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Anhydrous betaine 98%, formic acid 98% pure, d(+)-glucose ACS reagent anhydrous, starch for analysis soluble, microcrystalline cellulose extra pure (average particle size 90μm) and 4-methyl-2-pentanone (MIBK) were purchased from Acros Organics. d(−)-Fructose was supplied by Fisher. The water used in all experiments was a Millipore Milli-Q grade. 2.2 General procedure for conversion of d-fructose, d-glucose, starch and cellulose into HMF using betaine and formic acid in a H2O–MIBK biphasic system In a typical experiment, 0.18g (1.0mmol) of carbohydrate, 0.07g (0.59mmol) of betaine and 0.25g of HCOOH were introduced in a 10mL vial closed with a septum, followed by addition of 1–4mL of water and/or MIBK. Mono and biphasic batch reactions were carried out by means of microwave heating in a Anton Paar Monowave 300 apparatus and stirred at 600rpm for the desired time. The temperature in the reaction vessel was monitored by means of an IR sensor and the vial was pressurized in regard to the normal vapor pressure of the solution at defined reaction temperature. Each sample was diluted with acetonitrile to obtain 100mL of homogeneous solution and filtrated with 0.45μm PTFE syringe filter prior to analysis. Identical procedure was done starting from 180mg of starch or cellulose powder. 2.3 Product analysis Each sample of the reaction mixture was analyzed separately by means of Shimadzu Prominence HPLC. After reaction, the possible hexose traces were detected with a low temperature evaporative light scattering detector (ELSD-LTII) and the HMF concentration was quantified with a UV–vis detector (SPD-H20A) at a wavelength of 280nm. The column used was a Grace C18 column (250×4.6nm 5μm). The mobile phase was MeOH–H2O (1:1) solution flowing at a rate of 0.5mLmin−1. The column oven was set at 40°C. Regularly, the calibration was checked out in order to avoid eventual experimental errors associated with all measurements reported below. Hexose conversion rate (X, mol%) and 5-HMF yield (Y, mol%) were calculated by means of the following equations: X ( % ) = 1 − ( mole concentrations of hexose byproducts ) mole of concentration of initial hexose × 100 . Y ( % ) = mole of concentration of 5-HMF mole concentration of initial hexose × 100 . 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Determination of the preliminary optimal conditions Because of our first enthusiastic result demonstrated with betaine–HCOOH catalytic system employed for dehydrating d-xylose into furfural in water–clopentylmethyl ether (CPME) under microwave irradiation, some tries to transpose the methodology to HMF production were finally made [21]. The same substrate to catalyst ratio was kept unchanged in order to convert both d-fructose and d-glucose into HMF in aqueous CPME. For 1.0mmol of the sugar dissolved in 1.0mL of water, 0.25g of HCOOH and 0.07g of betaine were added to the solution and finally a pH value of 2.0 were determined before starting the experiment in presence of 3.0mL of CPME. Unfortunately, CPME was not a good solvent for extracting HMF, probably due to its poor solubility in the ether. In this regards, the reactions were all carried out in 4.0mL of sole water keeping the same catalyst ratio (Fig. 1 ). The most favorable temperature was determined at 160 and 190°C with higher value of HMF yields of 38 and 21% respectively for d-fructose and d-glucose. Regarding the selectivity, from d-fructose, the value showed an average value of 35% for temperature found between 160 and 180°C. In case of d-glucose, the value varied from 15 to 21% for the same range of temperature. Interestingly, when 0.14g of betaine was employed the yield of formed HMF reached a value of 29% from d-glucose with a complete conversion of the hexose. With no surprise, in sole water, the dehydration of d-glucose needs more energy to afford the desired HMF. It was notable that starting from d-fructose yields of HMF decreased with the increase of the temperature although the reverse phenomenon was observed starting from d-glucose. In order to increase the productivity, mass of d-fructose and d-fructose were doubled and quadrupled. In our hands, HMF yield give a value of 52% starting from d-fructose while HMF yield from d-glucose decreased gradually adding more sugar with a progressive increase of the humin formed (Fig. 2 ). A blank was also realized with 360mg of d-fructose in presence of 0.25g of formic acid without betaine. When heated at 160°C for 1h, only 33% of HMF yield was obtained. Concerning the selectivity of HMF starting from d-fructose (360mg), full conversion was observed after 1h at 160°C conducting to a selectivity of 52%. It was noteworthy that LA was not detected. By opposite, the maximum of HMF selectivity from d-glucose was observed at 180°C for 180mg of the sugar with a value of 21%. Even the dehydration is reported to be faster with d-fructose, the production of HMF seems to be independent of both sugar concentrations. These two points are important factors to determine the pathway to get higher yields of HMF. 3.2 Effects of water replacement by aqueous MIBK MIBK was chosen due to the fact this one of the most potent extractive solvent for HMF in a biphasic system. Considering our process, in order to improve the yield and the selectivity of HMF, dehydration of d-fructose and d-glucose was realized using the best above reaction conditions with different ratios of water–MIBK keeping the most effective substrate-catalytic system ratios demonstrated previously (Figs. 1 and 2). For each biphasic systems (4:0, 3:1, 2:2, 1:3, v/v), all results were reported in Fig. 3 . Our first trial involved d-fructose (360mg) and the catalytic system heated up for 1h in a water–MIBK biphasic system with a volume ratio (1:3, v/v). Despite the addition of the extractive solvent, no significant improvement of the HMF yield was recorded (55% vs 52%). With less of d-fructose (180mg vs 360mg), dehydration at 160°C for 1h furnished HMF with yields higher than 30%. In our hands, the maximum of yield was obtained for water–MIBK ratio (3:1, v/v) with a value of 82% and started to decrease by replacing H2O with MIBK to the sample. By opposite, at 190°C, the yield of HMF obtained from d-glucose never exceeded 51%. Starting from d-glucose, the most appropriate ratio of water–MIBK was different (2:2, v/v vs 3:1, v/v). Generally, the direct dehydration of d-glucose was reported to be difficult in one step without realize an enzymatic isomerization into d-fructose [22]. Due to the kinetic of the d-fructose dehydration, the rehydration of HMF did not occur easily despite the slight value of MIBK volume employed here, enough to entrap almost the entire target compound. Besides that, the absence of HMF degradation was also confirmed by the non-detection of LA through the HPLC analysis. 3.3 Influence of the reaction time on the HMF yield Interestingly, on Fig. 4 a, when heated at 160°C, using the volume ratio (water–MIBK, 1:3, v/v), the dehydration of 1.0mmol of d-fructose cannot give more of 55% HMF yield despite the residence time extension. Curiously, if the same reaction was carried out in an inverted volume ratio of the solvents (3:1, v/v), for 40min of stirring the yield gave the normal value of HMF yield currently encountered in literature, indeed 85%. This result confirms the fact that d-fructose needs less MIBK to produce HMF, but in a few delay. On Fig. 4b, for 1.0mmol of d-glucose, when heated at 190°C by means of the microwave oven when immersed in a water–MIBK biphasic system (2:2, v/v), just after 40min of heating, the HMF yield never really exceeded 51%. For longer reaction time, after 60min the yield remained stable. However for a period superior to 80min the HMF yield finally dropped to 30%. On the other hand, when the volume ratio decreased in favor to MIBK (1:3, v/v), the yield was restricted to 45% despite the time extension of the reaction. From a kinetic point of view, all reactions taking place here could be resumed in Scheme 1 . The kinetic of d-glucose conversion is generally characterized by a reversible isomerization leading to the d-fructose formation. In our study, unfortunately the direct d-glucose conversion was subjected to an excessive amount of humin generated during the process. The corresponding ODE (ordinary differential equations) could be written as follow and provided as equations (a)–(c): (a) d [ Glc ] d t = ( − k 1 + k ′ 1 ) [ Glc ] − k 3 [ Glc ] . (b) d [ F ] d t = − k 2 [ F ] + ( k 1 − k ′ 1 ) [ Glc ] . (c) d [ HMF ] d t = k 2 [ F ] . In our case, at 190°C, the formation of d-glucose from d-fructose ( k ′ 1 ) should be neglected compared to the d-fructose dehydration k 2 in the normal way. In this regards, only k 1 and k 2 should be considered. Surely, this model was overall adequate for determining the constant k 2 of direct conversion of d-fructose into HMF performed in the above two different water–MIBK volume ratios, e.g. those of (1:3) and (3:1) at 160°C. By using Eq. (c), k 2 gave both values of 0.0062 and 0.004min−1 respectively obtained in (3:1) and (1:3) water–MIBK volume ratios. 3.4 Reusability of the catalyst Regarding the good d-fructose loading influence reported in Fig. 2, several consecutive dehydration of 180mg d-fructose was performed using the rest of the above optimized conditions keeping the same betaine–formic acid catalytic system unchanged, when heated in a microwave oven for 40min (Fig. 5 ). The reaction was repeated until the volume of the aqueous layer reduced strongly or the amount of formed humin was too large course, under these conditions (7 cycles). Both first and second cycles gave only 82% of HMF yield probably due to possible increase in formic acid concentration during the process. Confirmation was done after measurement of the acidity that increased. Thus from the third cycle and until the end of the entire experiment the HMF yield remained almost constant with an average value of 99%. 3.5 Transformation of soluble starch and microcrystalline cellulose under optimized conditions The methodology was transposed to the polysaccharides such as soluble starch and microcrystalline cellulose. Due to the presence of d-glucose monomers, the experiment series was carried out using the apparently most appropriate water–MIBK volume ratio (2:2, v/v) determined previously in this study. Herein, for 1.0mmol of each polysaccharide, a lower value of pH was necessary to hydrolyze completely the biopolymer chains. Then, the reactions were performed in presence of 0.07g of betaine, but this time immersed in more HCOOH (0.50g vs 0.25g), leading to a pH value of 1.7. In sole water, when heated at 190°C for 1h, just 20% of HMF yield was obtained from the direct conversion of starch. The reactions were realized at different temperatures to compare the direct conversion into HMF for both polymers (Fig. 6 ). In fact, these phenomenons are in direct relation with all aspects of the polysaccharides structure, e.g. the polymerization degree (DP) and the nature of glycosidic bond between each d-glucose subunit. The crystallinity level and the water solubility of the material are also important factors and both are in direct relation with the number and the strength of the hydrogen bond formed between lateral hydroxyl groups on the polysaccharide chains. In case of cellulose, at 170°C, when heated for 1h, no trace of HMF was detected and the powder was recovered almost intact in the vessel, dispersed in the aqueous layer. However, at 200°C, the yield of HMF reached finally a value of 22% (Scheme 2 ). Cellulose hydrolysis leaded to the release of small insoluble d-glucose rich-oligomers without traces of d-fructose, it is possible to imagine that only free glucose sub-units are suddenly dehydrated into HMF. This hypothetic result is in accordance with a recent result obtained by HMF production study from cellulose in a biphasic system in presence of phosphated TiO2 nanoparticles under conventional heating [23]. Due to the slow hydrolysis explained by the existence of β-1,4 glycosidic bonds between the d-glucose subunits and quite exclusive in the crystalline cellulose structure. Interestingly, no humin was formed. Starting from starch with d-glucose units connected through α-1,4 glycosidic bonds, the hydrolysis is well known to be more easily cleaved in strong acidic condition. The resulted rich in short oligomers and d-glucose residues could become the main source to produce HMF in moderate yield of 20% after 60min of residence time at 190°C. Additional experiments were performed to measure the influence of the residence time on the formed HMF yields. In each case 1.0mmol of the biopolymer (based on monomer subunit) was dehydrated in presence of the same previous catalytic system, but introduced in two biphasic systems with different water–MIBK volume ratios (1:3 and 2:2, v/v). Here, the volume of MIBK was increased to potentially improve the HMF yield. Starting from cellulose at 200°C, the HMF yield never exceeded 26%, beside the increase of the yield was very linear by prolonging the reaction time (Fig. 7a). For a period found between 40 and 60min in water–MIBK (2:2, v/v), the HMF yields were slightly higher than those obtained with the other ratio at the same temperature. Despite slight volume of water, the oligomers are supposed to be enough available for further hydrolysis and dehydration into HMF which is similar in behavior with the dehydration of d-glucose itself. Starting from starch, the higher HMF yield was observed with water–MIBK ratio (1:3, v/v) and gave a value of 45% for 60min (Fig. 7b). After this period, by extending the residence time the HMF yield decreased and went under 28% with a volume ratio (2:2, v/v) the response was also linear. 4 Conclusion Using betaine and formic acid, four different carbohydrates sources were transformed into HMF in a short time without formation of levulinic acid and high selectivity of the target compound. The best yields were obtained using a minimum of MIBK volume, especially with d-fructose and the reusability of the catalytic system is also efficient for its higher loadings. By employing this system, cheaper cellulose could be also converted in HMF without non-desired humin production and hydrolyzate potentially ready for further enzymatic transformation into bioethanol. coredata.dc:description: A mixture of betaine–formic acid was employed to convert d-glucose and d-fructose into 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) with high selectivity and also for the direct conversion of water-soluble starch and microcrystalline insoluble cellulose. The reactions were performed in average of temperature found between 160 and 200°C regarding the nature of the substrate. The reactions were carried out under microwave heating and performed in a water–MIBK biphasic system at different ratios. In each case, the specific optimized condition gave values of HMF yields of 82%, 55%, 54% and 47% respectively from d-fructose, d-glucose, water-soluble starch and cellulose microcrystalline powder.
coredata.dc:title: Various carbohydrate precursors dehydration to 5-HMF in an acidic biphasic system under microwave heating using betaine as a co-catalyst
